pageTitle: Center fielder Carlos Gomez ends Milwaukee Brewers' Gold Glove drought | brewers.com
TableContextTimeStampBeforeTable: {1189=BOSTON -- Carlos Gomez waited five years for the Rawlings Gold Glove Award he expected to win with the Twins in 2008., 748=When Gomez was awarded the Gold Glove as the National League's top center fielder on Tuesday, he became the first Milwaukee player to take home the award since Robin Yount won as a shortstop in 1982, when Yount was a soon-to-be American League MVP and the Brewers were still licking their wounds from a Game 7 loss to the Cardinals in the World Series.}
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {6979=It is the 10th Gold Glove Award in Brewers history, including first baseman George Scott's five straight from 1972-76. The only Brewers outfielder to win before Gomez was Sixto Lezcano in 1979., 3319=And for the numbers folks, Gomez was also a worthy pick. According to FanGraphs.com, he led all outfielders with 38 defensive runs saved in 2013, trailing only Braves shortstop Andrelton Simmons (42) among Major League players. The next highest center fielder was Arizona's A.J. Pollock with 15 runs saved. McCutchen's DRS was seven, and Span's was three., 7195=Gomez spoke via telephone from the Dominican Republic, where he is nearly two weeks removed from an Oct. 17 surgery to remove loose bodies from his right (throwing) elbow. Gomez was bothered by pain in that joint for most of the season, one of a myriad of ailments that was a result of his all-out style of play., 5656=The play that probably defined his season came at Votto's expense on July 8 at Miller Park. The Brewers led by a run, but the Reds had a runner on base with two outs when Votto sent a deep drive to straightaway center field, where Gomez perfectly timed his leap to pull back what would have been a go-ahead home run and instead end the game., 6544="I have a lot of things that go through my mind," Gomez said. "The last seven years, I believe I'm one of the best center fielders in the game. It's my job. In 2008, I expected to get it, but because I was not doing really good offensively, they didn't give it to me., 4562=He said his favorite catch was not the home run robberies of Marlon Byrd, Carlos Gonzalez, John Mayberry Jr., Joey Votto or potentially Jay Bruce (players debated that one in the Brewers' own clubhouse), but a grab short of the wall in June in Houston, where Gomez climbed Tal's Hill in center field to take extra bases away from the Astros' Jason Castro. He made a sensational grab, rose to his knees and held his glove high in the air.}
textBeforeTable: 2013 Gold glove winners It had been a long time, and Gomez knew it. When Gomez was awarded the Gold Glove as the National League's top center fielder on Tuesday, he became the first Milwaukee player to take home the award since Robin Yount won as a shortstop in 1982, when Yount was a soon-to-be American League MVP and the Brewers were still licking their wounds from a Game 7 loss to the Cardinals in the World Series. That was nothing. For the Brewers, the wait was 31 years. BOSTON -- Carlos Gomez waited five years for the Rawlings Gold Glove Award he expected to win with the Twins in 2008. 0 COMMENTS + | MLB.com By Adam McCalvy / Carlos Gomez wins his first career Gold Glove in 2013, robbing home runs at a nearly daily clip at Miller Park 0:59 Gomez wins
textAfterTable: "That made me feel more excited and proud of myself," he said. "I give something to the organization, to the Milwaukee Brewers, that they didn't have for [31] years. This is the organization that made me the player that I am right now." That player beat fellow finalists Andrew McCutchen of the Pirates (last year's winner) and Denard Span of the Nationals under a new system of voting that combines the old way -- managers' and coaches' votes -- with advanced metrics. For the first time, Rawlings collaborated with the Society for American Baseball Research (SABR) to formally incorporate five defensive measures to the process, accounting for about 25 percent of the final vote. It turns out that Gomez excelled in both the old school and new school. For the eye test, he made at least four and perhaps five home run-robbing catches, including two that ended Brewers victories over the Reds at Miller Park. And for the numbers folks, Gomez was also a worthy pick. According to FanGraphs.com, he led all outfielders with 38 defensive runs saved in 2013, trailing only Braves shortstop Andrelton Simmons (42) among Major League players. The next highest center fielder was Arizona's A.J. Pollock with 15 runs saved. McCutchen's DRS was seven, and Span's was three. Gomez also fared well in ultimate zone rating, which attempts to measure a fielder's success in converting balls in his "zone" into outs.
